posts.name: Sean B
posts.cooked:
Recently Pathplanner 2025 was released. which is great. It seems like it brought a lot of amazing features. But does it make Choreo obselete?

We used Choreo last season to compensate for the fact that pathplanner could plan paths that were impossible to follow. We then used pathplanner to stitch together the paths with auto commands. My question mostly comes from my lack of detailed understanding but is there any reason to keep using Choreo now that pathplanner started tracking Swerve dynamics and Torque limits?

I hope this post isn‚Äôt repetitive, I‚Äôve seen some discussions but no direct comparison and I‚Äôm not sure how they compare now. Are paths still better if made through Choreo?

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: TLDR; no. The goals of the new pathplanner‚Äôs generation and Choreo‚Äôs generation is still fundamentally different. While pathplanner‚Äôs generation now respects swerve dynamics (improving the ability of them to work once generated), they wont necessarily be time optimal which is the fundamental goal of Choreo‚Äôs generation algorithm. Choreo‚Äôs generation algorithm is designed to find the path that takes the least time while still meeting the given constraints  (both user defined and from swerve dynamics). pathplanner‚Äôs optimiser should also help with path time but again doesn‚Äôt guarantee minimally timed paths.

I‚Äôd like to add onto what Jade said with the fact that the robot-side libraries are also diverging more. Choreo is adopting a trigger based auto command creation workflow while PathPlanner has stuck with the pre-made path following command style. Which one of those to favor is up to your personal style preferences but IMO is almost as if not just as important as the application when deciding which to use.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
Both Choreo and PathPlanner added support for trigger-based routines this year:

A graphical tool for planning time-optimized trajectories for autonomous mobile robots in the FIRST Robotics Competition.

https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-triggers.html

Oh nice, i hadn‚Äôt seen/heard that yet, thanks!

There is still a disambiguation between setting up the commands ‚Äúfreestanding‚Äù and having them directly attached to the routine though, which like I said does really just come down to workflow/style preference.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm not sure I understand what you mean, the trigger functionality looks similar to me between both libraries. With PathPlanner you can build triggers to commands in code, like with Choreo.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
The truth is that especially this year where paths are mostly straight-line drives, PathPlanner and Choreo will likely generate effectively equivalent paths, though I haven‚Äôt done any comparison testing to see if that‚Äôs true.

My advice if you‚Äôre making a decision at this point in the season is to stick with the tool you know. I don‚Äôt think Choreo is obsolete, but it‚Äôs definitely not game-changingly distinctive in this season.
